results.headline: Leading the Way Through the Smoke

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Addiction Incorporated

results.summary_short: In “Addiction Incorporated,” the whistle-blower Victor DeNoble brightens the depressing history of tobacco-industry deception over addiction to cigarettes.

results.headline: Prince of the Universe, and His Maid

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Piece of the Pie

results.summary_short: In “My Piece of the Pie,” Cédric Klapisch portrays the relationship between a business wheeler-dealer and his housekeeper.

results.headline: The Spy Who Emerged From the Fog

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy

results.summary_short: “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,” with Gary Oldman as George Smiley, skillfully mined from John le Carré’s book, is a mystery about spies spying on spies.

results.headline: Once a Prom Queen, Still a Spoiled Princess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Young Adult

results.summary_short: In “Young Adult,” Charlize Theron plays a pretty and poised but mean and self-pitying woman who tries to get out of a rut by returning home and reconnecting with her youth.

results.headline: Don’t Bother Checking In With This Baby Sitter

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sitter

results.summary_short: “The Sitter,” an on-and-off funny rehash of “Adventures in Babysitting,” centers on a college dropout who reluctantly agrees to mind three children for pay.

results.headline: A Struggling Actor Strays, and Pays

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seducing Charlie Barker

results.summary_short: The title character of “Seducing Charlie Barker” discovers that the ditzy starlet he sleeps with is smarter than she seems.

results.headline: Suffocated by Motherhood, and a Child Whose Hold Still Lingers
results.display_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Need to Talk About Kevin

results.summary_short: “We Need to Talk About Kevin” is Lynne Ramsay’s disturbing movie about the mother of a child who goes on a killing spree at his high school.

results.headline: Brawling for Money, Clan and Just Because

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knuckle

results.summary_short: Ian Palmer’s documentary “Knuckle” shows plenty of fights among Irish travelers, but doesn’t delve into their complexities.

results.headline: Unlikely Hero in an Underground Hideout, Away From the Nazis

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Darkness

results.summary_short: In “In Darkness,” set in the sewers of Lvov, Poland, a righteous gentile selflessly assists in the survival of a handful of persecuted Jews.

results.headline: Sharing the Regrets, and the Sex and Drugs

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Melt With You

results.summary_short: “I Melt With You” stars Rob Lowe, Jeremy Piven, Thomas Jane and Christian McKay as college friends now in middle age rejoining for a week of debauchery and soul-searching.

results.headline: Cold, Claustrophobia and Confetti: What Fun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of New Year's Eve

results.summary_short: “New Year’s Eve,” Garry Marshall’s latest film, brings stars together in Times Square.

results.headline: Girls Just Wanna Shoot Up a Diner

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Catch .44

results.summary_short: “Catch .44” features Bruce Willis as a drug lord, Malin Akerman as a woman on a mission, and a lot of shooting.

results.headline: In Wake of Terror Attacks, Unlikely Bonds

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of London River

results.summary_short: “London River,” by Rachid Bouchareb, is set in the aftermath of the July 2005 London transit system bombings.

results.headline: Loving Portrayal of a Beiruti Matriarch

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grandma, A Thousand Times

results.summary_short: In “Grandma, a Thousand Times” the director Mahmoud Kaabour turns his camera on his spirited grandmother and her rich memories.

results.headline: A Family’s Irreparable Loss for the Crime of Being Sikh

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Singh

results.summary_short: The Bollywood veteran Puneet Issar directs and stars in “I Am Singh,” about a man who faces anti-Sikh sentiment as he seeks justice after the murder of his brother.

results.headline: An Intimate Tour of a Gleaming German Nuclear Plant

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under Control

results.summary_short: “Under Control” is a documentary tour of German nuclear power plants and the policies that sustain them.

results.headline: The Blood Runs Freely, but the Dogs Can’t

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Yellow Sea

results.summary_short: The South Korean film “The Yellow Sea” is a morality tale full of shocking images and rousing chase scenes.

results.headline: Fury, Up Close and Personal, at the Lingering Effects From the BP Oil Spill

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Big Fix

results.summary_short: “The Big Fix,” directed by Josh Tickell and Rebecca Harrell Tickell, is an enraged exposé of the crimes of Big Oil.

results.headline: Only One Thing on His Mind

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shame

results.summary_short: In “Shame,” the new feature from the British artist turned filmmaker Steve McQueen, the protagonist is a handsome, youngish Manhattanite who is hooked on sex.

results.headline: He’s the Hero of the People, and He Hates It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coriolanus

results.summary_short: In his directing debut, Ralph Fiennes adds modern weaponry to Shakespeare’s “Coriolanus.”
